EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


We have adopted this Program in order to implement 40 C.F.R. 68, the federal requirements regulating Risk Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.

This Program will help prevent the occurrence of, or minimize the consequences of, catastrophic releases by stating our policies and procedures for the management of process hazards in start-up, operation, inspection, maintenance and the other matters addressed in the federal standard.

Our Program calls for maximum employee participation and includes all elements of the employee participation provisions of the standard.  We shall, as a minimum: (1) consult with employees and their representatives on the conduct and development of the process hazard review and other elements of the risk management plan, and (2) provide to our employees and their representatives access to the process hazard review and all other information required to be developed under that standard.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The City of Galveston believes that preventative maintenance is the key to minimizing the potential for accidental releases.  Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) have been reviewed and revised to enable the employees to perform their work in a safe and efficient manner.

The EPA has adopted a policy for non-responding facilities (another entity has agreed in advance to respond to the release).  This facility is a non-responding facility.  The City of Galveston Fire Department is the first responder.

This emergency response program does not include responses to incidental releases of hazardous substances, including chlorine, where the substances can be ?adsorbed, neutralized, or otherwise controlled at the time of the release by employees in the immediate release area, or by maintenance personnel?.

The City of Galveston has taken steps to train the operators, supervisors, and maintenance crews to be knowledgeable in the emergency response program.  The training includes cl

assroom and hands on training on the proper use of emergency response equipment and procedures.  Above all, all employees know where the phone numbers of the first responders are located should a release occur.






Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The 59th Street Water Pump Station utilizes chlorine for disinfection.  The maximum inventory and threshold quantity for Chlorine is shown below.  Ammonia inventory is always below the RMP threshold of 20,000 pounds.  Process Safety Information is presented for ammonia for employee awareness.  The same emergency plan is used in the case of an ammonia leak.


Chemical    Maximum Inventory (lb.)    Threshold Quantity (lb.)
        
Chlorine    8,000    2,500

Offsite Consequence Analysis

The offsite consequence analysis includes a worst-case release scenario and an alternative release scenario as defined in 40 C.F.R. 68.  A dense-gas dispersion model (SLAB) was used to determine endpoint distances for both scenarios.  A dense-gas model is required since chlorine is heavier than air.  The model?s input parameters are summarized in the table below.

 General Accidental Release Prevention Program

The City of Galveston has implemented a General Accidental Release Prevention Program to minimi

ze releases.  This Program includes:  safety information on the covered chemicals, hazard reviews, operating and maintenance procedures, training, compliance audits, incident investigations, and emergency response procedures.

Five-year Accident History

In the last 5 years, there have not been any accidental releases from the covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage.


Planned Changes to Improve Safety    

The city will address the recommendations of the process hazards assessment for all areas of the prevention program and the emergency response program.

II.  CHLORAMINE PROCESS



     A.   Process Chemistry

     

            Chlorine  is used to disinfect the water  effluent

        prior  to  discharging into the water  supply  system.

        Chlorination  capacities  are  generally  selected  to

        meet

the  specific design criteria of  the  state  or

        other   regulatory  agencies  controlling  the   water

        supply  system.   In any case, where the  residual  in

        the   effluent   is  determined  by  onsite   testing.

        Ammonia  is  added  to  the  water  immediately  after

        chlorination   to  provide  a  more  stable   chlorine

        residual.



           The general chloramine equations are as follows:



           Cl2 + H2O  HOCl + H+ + Cl-

           NH4 + H2O  NH3 + H3O+

           NH3 + HOCl  NH2Cl + H2O

           NH3 + 2HOCl  NHCl2 + 2H2O

           NH3 + 3HOCl  NCl3 + 3H2O



        Free-residual   chlorine  is  readily  obtained   with

        waters of low chlorine demand.  The maintenance  of  a

        residual  of  free chlorine within a  water  treatment

        plant  minimizes  the  growth  of  microorganisms  and

        slimes  on sand filters and in settling basins.   Free

        chlorine  facilitates  the oxidation  and  removal  of

        inorganic  reducing agents and sometimes improves  the

        coagulation behavior of certain waters.



        The  practice  of  combined-residual  chlorination  is

        particularly    applicable    to    post-disinfection.

        Residual  chlorine that is combined  with  ammonia  in

        the  form  of chloramines is less reactive  than  free

        chlorine,  and  thus persists for  longer  periods  of

        time   subsequent   to   chlorination.    The   useful

        functions  of long-lasting combined chlorine residuals

        are:



        1.  Control of algae and bacterial aftergrowth;

         2.   Reduction  of  dead-end  red-water  problems  in

distribution systems; and

         3.   Bactericidal protection of drinking  water  from

recontamination.



        An  additional purpose of chlorination is to avoid the

        formation  of  malodorous chlorophenols  when  phenols

        are  present  in the water,

which is to be disinfected

        by  chlorine.  Chloramines will not react with phenols

        to  form  chlorophenols nearly to the extent  as  will

        free chlorine species.

     

     B. Maximum Inventory



            Chlorine is supplied as a liquefied gas under high

        pressure  from one (1) 1-ton container.   The  maximum

        inventory  for  chlorine is four (4) 1-ton  containers

        or  8,000  pounds.  Equipment manuals,  which  include

        component  specifications, operating  parameters,  and

        maintenance procedures, may be found in Appendix B.



     C. Process



            The  chlorination  system  includes  the  chlorine

        supply,  chlorinators,  and injectors.   The  chlorine

        injector  is the controlling component.  The  injector

        is  used  to create a vacuum that is used to draw  the

        chlorine  gas from the chlorine container through  the

        chlorinator,  and into the injector.  The  chlorinator

        meters   the  volume  of  chlorine  solution  at   the

        injector,  the  chlorine  dissolves  in  the  injector

        water  supply  to form hypochlorous  acid.   From  the

        injector, the hypochlorous acid solution flows to  the

        point  where  it  is  injected into  the  water.   The

        differential  pressure  across  the  chlorinator  (the

        measuring  device) may be held constant or  varied  in

        accordance  with the flow by changing  the  degree  of

        vacuum.



            The ammonia tank gravity feeds the ammonia through

        the  metering equipment to the injection  point.   The

        ammonia  reacts with the chlorine to form chloramines,

        which  are less reactive than free chlorine, and  thus

        persists  for  longer periods of  time  subsequent  to

        chlorination.

                   PROCESS HAZARD ASSESSMENT

The  Process  Hazard Assessment includes the Offsite  Consequence

Analysis, Process Hazard Review, and the 5-year Accident History.



I.   OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



     A.   The offsite consequence analysis (OCA) includes a worst-case

          release scenario and an alternative release scenario as defined

          in 40 C. F. R. Part 68.  A dense-gas dispersion model (SLAB) was

          used to estimate the end point distances for both scenarios.  A

          dense-gas model is required since chlorine is heavier than air.

          The model?s input parameters are summarized in the table below.

          The  site also utilizes a maximum of four (4) drums  of

          20  %  ammonium hydroxide in the chlorination  process.

          This  amount is below the threshold quantity (49 drums)

          so it is not covered under the RMP regulations.

          

     B.   Worst-Case Release Scenario Analysis

     

          1.   An analysis of one worst-case release scenario was conducted

               to estimate the greatest distance from a point of release to the

               end point for chlorine.

          2.   A worst-case release quantity is predetermined as the

               greatest amount held in a single vessel, taking into account

               administrative controls that would be released in

the event of an

               accident.  The maximum quantity for chlorine is a 2,000 pound (1

               ton) instantaneous release of gas over a 10 minute period.

          

     C.   Alternative Release Scenario Analysis



          1.   The alternative release scenario was determined from the

               results of the Process Hazard Review and from the review of

               historical accident data.

          2.   The most likely accident to occur is a disconnection of the

               flex line that connects the containers to the header line.

          3.   The release duration was assumed to be a 10 minute jet

               release of gas and liquid.

II.  5-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



     In  the  last  5  years, there has not been  any  accidental

     releases  from the covered process that resulted in  deaths,

     injuries, or significant property damage on site,  or  known

     offsite  deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place,

     property damage, or environmental damage.

     

III. PROCESS HAZARD REVIEW



     A  Process  Hazard  Review  was conducted  to  identify  the

     following:

     

     ?    The hazards associated with the chlorine processes;

     ?    Opportunities for equipment malfunction or human error that

       could cause a release;

     ?    Safeguards that will co

ntrol the hazards or prevent the

       malfunction or error; and

     ?    Steps to detect or monitor releases.



     A  What-if  and Checklist Analysis was used to  conduct  the

     review.   The  review  team utilized  the  What-if  Analysis

     technique to brainstorm the various types of accidents  that

     could occur within the chlorine system.  Then the team  used

     one  or  more checklists to help fill in any gaps that  were

     missed.





     The What-if questions covered the following areas:

     

     ?    Movement of containers;

     ?    Piping from containers to header lines;

     ?    Chlorine headers in the Chlorination Room;

?    Piping from Chlorination Room to injectors; and

?    General areas.



     The Checklists covered the following areas:

     

     ?    Process Safety Information;

     ?    Operating Procedures;

     ?    Training;

     ?    Incident Investigation;

     ?    Emergency Planning and Response; and

     ?    Compliance Audits.

                           SECTION 4

                               

             OPERATING AND MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES





I.   OPERATING PROCEDURES



        A. The City of Galveston developed and implemented

        written standard operating procedures (SOPs) that are

        consistent with the Process Safety Information

        (Section 2 of this Program).  Those procedures

        provide clear instructions for safely conducting

        activities involved in the chlorine systems

        consistent with the process safety information.  They

        address the following:



        1.  The steps for each operating phase:



            a.  Initial startup;

            b.  Normal operation;

            c.  Normal shutdown.



        2.  Operating limits:



            a.  Consequences of deviation;

            b.  Steps required to correct and/or avoid

deviation; and

c.  Equipment.



           Copies of the operating procedures are readily

        accessible in the Superintendent?s office to

        employees who work in or maintain the chlorine

        systems.



           The operating procedures are reviewed as often as

        necessary to assure that they reflect current

        operating practice, including changes that result

        from changes in process chemicals, technology, and

        equipment; and changes to facilities.



II.  MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES



     The City of Galveston developed and implemented written

     maintenance procedures that are consistent with the

     Process Safety Information (Section 2 of this Program).

     Those procedures are used to maintain the on-going

     mechanical integrity of the chlorine process equipment.



     The City of Galveston trained all present employees and

     will train future employees involved in maintaining the

     on-going mechanical integrity of the chorine process

     equipment.  To ensure that those employees can perform

     the job tasks in a safe manner, each employee is trained

     in the hazards of the process, how to avoid or correct

     unsafe conditions, and in the procedures applicable to

     the employee?s job tasks.



     The City of Galveston has a SOP in place that ensures

     that each contract maintenance employee is trained to

     perform the maintenance procedures developed under

     Section A (above).



     The City of Galveston performs routine inspections and

     tests on process equipment.  Inspecting and testing

     procedures follow recognized and generally accepted good

     engineering practices.  The frequency of the inspections

     and tests of process equipment are consistent with

     applicable manufacturer?s recommendations, industry

     standards or codes, good engineering practices, and prior

     operating experience.



     The City of Galveston makes an ann

ual certification that

     those operating and maintenance procedures are both

     current and accurate.  The Standard Operating Procedures

     covered under this Plan may be found in Appendix E.















                           SECTION 5

                               

                           TRAINING





     A. Initial Training



           Except as specified in Part B. (below), each

        employee presently involved in a process, and each

        employee before working in a newly assigned process,

        is trained in an overview of the process and in the

        operating procedures as specified in Section 4 of

        this Program.  The training will include emphasis on

        the specific safety and health hazards, procedures,

        and safe practices applicable to the employee's job

        tasks.



        B. Refresher and Supplemental Training for Operations



           Refresher and supplemental training is provided to

        each employee involved in operating a process at

        least every three years (and more often if necessary)

        in order to assure that the employee understands and

        adheres to the current operating procedures of the

        process.



        C. Refresher and Supplemental Training for Emergency

        Response



           Refresher and supplemental training is provided to

        each employee involved in emergency response on an

        annual basis (and more often if necessary) in order

        to assure that the employee understands and adheres

        to the current emergency response procedures.



        D. Training Documentation



           The City of Galveston?s training program ensures

        that each such employee has received, successfully

        completed, and understood such training.  Training

        documentation contains, as a minimum, the following

        information and may be found in Appendix F.



           1.  The identity of th

e employee,

           2.  The date of training, and

               3.    The means and methods that were used in

            order to verify that the employee understood the

            training.



        E. Training Course



           During each training session, each student is

        provided a handout for future reference.  The handout

        provides technical and regulatory information

        specific to the particular course, as well as

        information on good practices.



The training is conducted using City of Galveston personal

protective equipment (PPE), including self-contained breathing

apparatus (SCBA's), and when available with employees

personally assigned respirators.  This allows for students to

be trained on the equipment they may actually use.



Upon successful completion of the course, each participant

receives a certificate of completion for this training.  The

certificate documents successful completion of the course with

satisfactory exam and performance grades during field and

tabletop exercises.



It includes the employee's name and social security number,

the duration and date, the complete subject matter that

directly reflects the applicable requirements, and the

instructor's name.

                           SECTION 6

                               

                       COMPLIANCE AUDITS

                               



        A. The City of Galveston?s 59th Street Water Pump

        Station process safety management system will be

        regularly evaluated in order to:



        1.  Measure its effectiveness;

        2.  Direct our attention to potential weaknesses in

the system;

               3.    Verify that the procedures and practices

            that we have developed under the EPA standard are

            adequate; and

        4.  Assure that all required procedures and practices

are being followed.



     B. The evaluation will be conducted at least every three

years.

C. It will be conducted by at least one person

knowledgeable in the process.



     D. The findings of the audit will be developed into a

report.



        E. The audit team will promptly determine and

        document an appropriate response to each of the

        findings of the compliance audit, and will document

        that deficiencies have been corrected.



        F. The two most recent compliance audit reports will

        be retained in the RMP and may be found in Appendix

        G.











                               SECTION 7

                                   

                        INCIDENT INVESTIGATION





        A.   All incidents will be investigated that have either

        resulted in a catastrophic release of a highly hazardous

        chemical in the workplace, or could have reasonably resulted

        in a release.



        B.   Each such incident investigation will be initiated as

        promptly as possible, but not later than 48 hours following

        the incident.



        C.   An incident investigation team will be established to

        thoroughly investigate and analyze each such incident.  The

        membership of the investigation team will include at least

        one person knowledgeable in the process involved, including a

        contract employee if the incident involved work of the

        contractor, and other persons with appropriate knowledge and

        experience.



        D.   The investigation team must prepare a report at the

        conclusion of each investigation which includes at a minimum:



        ?    Date of the incident,

        ?    Date investigation began,

        ?    A description of the incident,

        ?    The factors that contributed to the incident, and

        ?    Any recommendations for future prevention/mitigation resulting

          from the investigation.

                                   

        E.   The City of Galveston has establishe

d a system to

        promptly address and resolve the incident report's findings

        and recommendations.  All corrective actions and resolutions

        that are taken in response shall be documented.



        F.   The report of the investigation team will be reviewed

        with all affected personnel, whose job tasks are relevant to

        the incident findings, including contract employees where

        applicable.



        G.   All incident investigation reports shall be retained for

        five years and may be found in Appendix H.

                    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN





I.   PURPOSE AND SCOPE

     

     The    City    of   Galveston   has   developed   this    written

     Emergency    Response   Plan   for   the   59th   Street    Water

     Treatment   Plant  (WP)  to  provide  guidance   fo

r   responding

     to    accidental   releases   of   chlorine.    The   plan    was

     developed   in  accordance  with  Title  40  of   the   Code   of

     Federal    Regulations   (40   CFR),   Part   68,   Subpart    E.

     Emergency    response    procedures   are    necessary    because

     accidents   can  occur,  even  with  the  best  safety   programs

     in   place.    Emergency  response  is  to   be   undertaken   to

     reduce   the   severity  of  a  release  and  protect  employees,

     emergency    responders,   and   the    public    from    harmful

     exposure to chlorine.

     

     A. APPLICATION



        The   WP   is   subject   to   the  Clean   Air   Act?s   Risk

        Management   Program   (RMP)   regulations,   which    require

        emergency      response     actions      including      public

        notification,    emergency   health   care,   and    emergency

        training    to    respond   to   an   offsite    release    of

        chlorine.   The   Environmental   Protection   Agency    (EPA)

        risk    management    regulations   require    that    at    a

        minimum,    plans    must   be   developed    for    notifying

        offsite    responders   and   providing   first    aid    (for

        facilities   that  will  not  respond  with  its   employees);

        for   community   notification  and  coordination   with   the

        community   response   plan;  for  using,   maintaining,   and

        testing   emergency  response  systems  and   equipment;   and

        employee training.

          

          The  Emergency  Response  Plan  program  shall  include  the

following elements:

          

          ?     Emergency escape procedures and emergency escape route

            assignments;

          ?     Procedures to be followed by employees who  remain  to

            operate critical plant operations before they evacuate;

          ?    Procedures to a

ccount for all employees after emergency

            evacuation has been completed;

          ?    Rescue and medical duties for those employees who are to

            perform them;

          ?    Preferred means of reporting fires and other emergencies;

          ?     Names and regular job titles of persons or departments

            who can be contacted for further information of duties under

            the plan;

          ?    An emergency alarm system shall be established;

          ?     The  types  of  evacuation to  be  used  in  emergency

            circumstances shall be established in the emergency plan; and

          ?    Training of employees to assist in the safe and orderly

            emergency evacuation of employees.

          

             The   Emergency  Response  Plan  developed  herein  shall

        be   coordinated   with  the  community   emergency   response

        plan  developed  under  42  U.  S.  C.  11003.   Upon  request

        by   the   local  emergency  planning  committee   (LEPC)   or

        emergency    response    officials,    WP    shall    promptly

        provide   to   the   local   emergency   response   officials,

        information   necessary   for  developing   and   implementing

        the community response plan.



     B. EXEMPTIONS



            The   contents   of   this  emergency   response   program

        apply   to   the   entire  WP,  although   it   is   primarily

        intended   to   address  a  release  of  chlorine   from   the

        WP?s    chlorination   process.    Chlorine   is   the    only

        regulated   substance   in   the   water   treatment   process

        that are present above threshold quantities.



            This   emergency   response  program  does   not   include

        responses     to    incidental    releases    of     regulated

        substances,   including   chlorine,   where   the   substances

        can     be     ?absorb

ed,    neutralized,     or     otherwise

        controlled  at  the  time  of  the  release  by  employees  in

        the    immediate    release   area,    or    by    maintenance

        personnel?.

III. REPORTING OF EMERGENCIES



     A. PROCEDURES



             In  the  event  that  there is a fire  or  a  release  of

        chlorine,    the   person(s)   discovering   the    fire    or

        release  is  to  immediately  report  the  incident   to   the

        Operations   Manager  or  person  designated  in  his   place.

        If   the  emergency  is  critical,  call  911  before  calling

        the   Operations  Manager.    The  Operations   Manager   will

        call   the   Fire   Department  if  necessary  and   determine

        if a reportable quantity (RQ) release has occurred.



             Information  to  be  reported  to  emergency   responders

        should include the following (upon calling 911):



          ?    Chemical(s) released,

          ?    Estimated quantity released,

          ?    Time and duration of the release,

          ?    Evacuation and/or sheltering plans, and

?     Name  and  telephone  number of the  person(s)  to  be

            contacted for further information.



IV.  EMERGENCY EVACUATION



     A. EMERGENCY ALARM SYSTEM



             If   a   release   of  chlorine  occurs,   the   chlorine

        sensors   will  sound  an  audible  alarm  and  activate   the

        strobe   light  on  top  of  the  building.    A   signal   is

        also   sent  to  the  operations  building.   THERE   ARE   NO

        OTHER  AUDIBLE  OR  VISUAL  ALARMS  AT  THE  PLANT  THAT  WILL

        SIGNAL THAT A CHLORINE RELEASE HAS OCCURRED.



              A   wind  sock,  located  on  top  of  the  chlorination

        building,    indicates   wind   direction.    All    employees

        should   note   the  wind  direction  and  move   up-wind   or

        cross-wind to a release of chlorine.





     B. TYPES OF EVACUATION



              In  the  event  of  a  release,  employees  will  either

        be   required  to  evacuate  the  plant  or  be  sheltered  in

        place.    This   will  be  dependent  upon   wind   direction,

        severity   of   the  release,  and  in  what   part   of   the

        plant the release has occurred.



     C. EMERGENCY EVACUATION AND SHELTERING



              In   the   event   of  an  emergency,   the   Operations

        Manager   or   his  designee  will  determine   if   employees

        will   need   to  evacuate  the  plant  or  be  sheltered   in

        place.    If  evacuation  is  necessary,  employees  will   be

        directed   to   report   to   one  of   the   four   following

        fencelines:



          ?    North,

          ?    East,

          ?    West, or

          ?    South



              Evacuation   to  these  locations  will   be   dependent

        upon   wind  direction  and  where  a  release  has  occurred.

        Evacuation   routes  to  these  locations  have  been   posted

        at   locations   throughou

t  the  plant  and  are   noted   on

        the   site   map   that  is  included  with   this   Emergency

        Response   Plan.   Employees   will   not   be   allowed    to

        return  to  the  plant  until  they  have  been  directed   to

        do   so   by   the   Operations  Manager   or   one   of   his

        designates.



            If sheltering in place is necessary, employees

        will be directed to report to the following location:



          ?    The Operations Building



            Employees are to remain in the Operations Building

        until emergency response crews have determined it is

        safe to leave.





     D. COMMUNICATION



             Directions  to  either evacuate  the  plant  or  move  to

        the   designated   sheltering  in  place  location   will   be

        broadcast over the two-way radio.









     E. ACCOUNTING FOR EMPLOYEES



             If   evacuation   from  the  plant   or   sheltering   in

        place   becomes   necessary,  the  Operations   Manager   will

        account  for  employees  by  making  a  head  count  from  the

        plant?s      employee      attendance/work      list       and

        contractors/visitors sign in.



     F. CRITICAL PLANT OPERATIONS PROCEDURES



              Prior    to    evacuation   from   the   plant    and/or

        sheltering   in   place,   the  Chief   Plant   Operator   and

        Plant    Operator   will   each   don   appropriate   personal

        protective    equipment   (PPE)   and   a    self    contained

        breathing   apparatus   (SCBA)  as   necessary.    The   Chief

        Plant   Operator   and   Plant   Operator   will   shut   down

        systems as necessary.



            If  evacuation  of  the  plant  has  been  ordered,  above

        personnel   will   report   to   the   designated   evacuation

        location   once   emergency  shut-down  has  been   completed.

        If   she

ltering   in  place  has  been  ordered,   the   above

        personnel will remain in operations.



     G. OFF-SITE EMERGENCY RESPONSE



             In  the  event  that  a  release  of  chlorine  threatens

        or   actually   moves   off-site,  the  fire   department   or

        their   designee   will  be  responsible   for   communicating

        and    notifying    affected   off-site   populations    about

        what actions to take.



V.   RESCUE AND MEDICAL DUTIES



     A. EMERGENCY RESPONSE



              The    WP   has   elected   to   be   a   non-responding

        facility.   Therefore,   any   rescue   or   medical    duties

        will   be   performed   by   trained   personnel   with    the

        Galveston Fire Department  or EMS.



             Any   plant  employee  that  is  sent  to  the   hospital

        during  an  emergency  must  be  accompanied  by  another   WP

        employee.    If  possible  an  MSDS  or  a  copy  of   medical

        procedures   for  the  treatment  of  exposure   to   chlorine

        should    accompany    the    injured    employee    to    the

        hospital.    This   will  be  helpful  to  medical   personnel

        who will treat the injured employee(s).



VI.  TRAINING



     A. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN



              Each    WP    employee   should   receive    orientation

        training   regarding   the   facility?s   emergency   response

        program.    Refresher   training  should   be   presented   at

        least   annually  and  at  a  minimum  cover   the   following

        elements:



          ?    Discussion of the Emergency Response Plan;

          ?     Clear definition of the roles and responsibilities  of

            each employee;

          ?    Checklist for actions to be taken;

          ?    Telephone list updates for personnel and agencies to be

            notified;

          ?    First aid and CPR training;

          ?    Ch

lorine hazards;

          ?    Do?s and don?ts during an emergency;

          ?    Emergency response and safety equipment;

          ?     Diagrams  showing  evacuation  routes  and  sheltering

            location(s);

          ?     Documentation of all training, including a list of the

            personnel  trained,  date  training  was  completed,   and

            subjects/material covered.



             WP   personnel  will  perform  periodic  drills  to  test

        the    participant?s    reactions   and    effectiveness    in

        implementing   the   Emergency  Response   Plan.    Full-scale

        emergency   drills  will  be  conducted  at  least   annually.

        These    drills   will   include   involvement   of    outside

        emergency     response    crews,    plant    personnel     and

        management.    Periodic   in-plant   drills   will   also   be

        conducted   using   different   simulated   release    events,

        and involve as many plant personnel as possible.



VII. PLAN REVIEW AND MODIFICATION



     The  Emergency  Response  Plan  will  be  reviewed  annually   or

     when  a  significant  process  and  safety  change  takes  place.

     The Plan will also be modified as needed.
